citations.narrative:
The acquisition and disposition records at the facility are not being kept up to date. There are no dispositions recorded for
sales and/or deaths of several species including American Mouflon, Degus, a Richardson’s Ground Squirrel, and
Domestic Sheep. Additionally, there are no acquisition records indicating births of several different species on site
including Degus, Domestic Chickens, and Domestic Pigeons. Accurate records of animals on hand, including acquisitions
and dispositions (purchases/births and sales/deaths) are necessary to assess the health and wellbeing of the animals on
site and allow tracking of animals being used for regulatory purposes. Correct by 18 December 2024 by ensuring the
inventory of all animals on hand is up to date and all acquisitions and dispositions are being recorded including animals
born on site or any deaths.

Several enclosures are not being maintained to protect the animals from injury. In the Dall Sheep enclosure, the ram has
damaged the run-in shelter by pushing the entire back wall out at an angle exposing sharp screws and creating holes in
both side panels exposing sharp edges of broken wood. In one of the silver fox enclosures, the underlying dig wire has
been exposed in about 5 areas with several inch gaps below the wire where a limb could become entrapped. The
Patagonian Cavy enclosure has a similar area of exposed dig wire in one corner of the enclosure. The dingo enclosure
has dig wire that is buckling up in several places and starting to protrude through the dirt/sand floor. Having exposed
wires, sharp edges, or screws can lead to animals becoming injured in their primary enclosure. Correct by 18 December
2024 by ensuring the indoor and outdoor housing facilities are structurally sound and shall be maintained in good repair to
protect the animals from injury and to contain the animals.

citations.desc: Cleaning, sanitization, housekeeping, and pest control.
citations.narrative:
There is an excessive amount of excreta in the cockatiel enclosure. The floor of the enclosure is primarily covered with
mulch and removed and replaced on a routine basis. However, the population of cockatiels in the enclosure has
increased significantly due to breeding and the enclosure floor has large quantities of excreta and feathers especially
around the perimeter. Excessive excreta in primary enclosures can soil the birds, increase disease hazards, and attract
pests into the enclosure. Correct by 11 December 2024 by removing excreta and food waste from primary enclosures and
from under and around primary enclosures as often as necessary to prevent excessive accumulation and soiling of the
birds, and to reduce disease hazards, insects, pests, and odors.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the licensee.
n

narrative:
2.75(b)(1) 
   
Records: Dealers and exhibitors. 
The acquisition and disposition records at the facility are not being kept up to date. There are no dispositions recorded for 
sales and/or deaths of several species including American Mouflon, Degus, a Richardson’s Ground Squirrel, and 
Domestic Sheep. Additionally, there are no acquisition records indicating births of several different species on site 
including Degus, Domestic Chickens, and Domestic Pigeons. Accurate records of animals on hand, including acquisitions 
and dispositions (purchases/births and sales/deaths) are necessary to assess the health and wellbeing of the animals on 
site and allow tracking of animals being used for regulatory purposes. Correct by 18 December 2024 by ensuring the 
inventory of all animals on hand is up to date and all acquisitions and dispositions are being recorded including animals 
born on site or any deaths. 
3.125(a) 
   
Facilities, general. 
Several enclosures are not being maintained to protect the animals from injury. In the Dall Sheep enclosure, the ram has 
damaged the run-in shelter by pushing the entire back wall out at an angle exposing sharp screws and creating holes in 
both side panels exposing sharp edges of broken wood. In one of the silver fox enclosures, the underlying dig wire has 
been exposed in about 5 areas with several inch gaps below the wire where a limb could become entrapped. The 
Patagonian Cavy enclosure has a similar area of exposed dig wire in one corner of the enclosure. The dingo enclosure 
has dig wire that is buckling up in several places and starting to protrude through the dirt/sand floor. Having exposed 
wires, sharp edges, or screws can lead to animals becoming injured in their primary enclosure. Correct by 18 December 
2024 by ensuring the indoor and outdoor housing facilities are structurally sound and shall be maintained in good repair to 
protect the animals from injury and to contain the animals. 
3.158(a)(1) 
   
Cleaning, sanitization, housekeeping, and pest control. 
There is an excessive amount of excreta in the cockatiel enclosure. The floor of the enclosure is primarily covered with 
mulch and removed and replaced on a routine basis. However, the population of cockatiels in the enclosure has 
increased significantly due to breeding and the enclosure floor has large quantities of excreta and feathers especially 
around the perimeter. Excessive excreta in primary enclosures can soil the birds, increase disease hazards, and attract 
pests into the enclosure. Correct by 11 December 2024 by removing excreta and food waste from primary enclosures and

from under and around primary enclosures as often as necessary to prevent excessive accumulation and soiling of the 
birds, and to reduce disease hazards, insects, pests, and odors. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the licensee. 
 
 n
